lines.text: [panicked]
Fire! Fire! Fire!
[gets to the fire station]
Fire! Fire! Fire!
[finds the firemen]
Fire!
[nobody moves]
Fire!
[they look weirdly at him]
FIRE!
[still no movement]
Cat...?
[everybody gets on their feet]
Where's my dinner?
When your father was here, I used to think, "This was it. This is the way it was always going to be. I had the right house. I had the right car. I had the right life."
There is no right house. There is no right car.
God, my face must be a mess.
It looks great.
Honey, it's really sweet of you, but I'm sure it does not look "great."
Sure it does. Come here.
I'm 40 years old. I mean, it's not supposed to be like this.
It's not supposed to be anything. Hold still.
How'd you get so smart all of a sudden?

[long slow smile]
I had a good day.

Up until now everything around here has been, well, pleasant. Recently certain things have become unpleasant. Now, it seems to me that the first thing we have to do is to separate out the things that are pleasant from the things that are unpleasant.
Honey! I'm home.

[bangs the gavel]
You're out of order!
Why am I out of order?
[approaches Big Bob]
Because I'm not gonna let you turn this courtroom into a circus!
Well, I don't think it's a circus, and I don't think they do, either.
[David turns to look at the crowd, where many of the black-and-white people are changing into color. There are gasps and murmurs. Jennifer grins]

[bangs the gavel]
This behavior must stop at once.
But see? That's just the point! It can't stop at once, because it's in you, and you can't stop something that's inside you.
It is not inside *me*!

[amused]
Oh, sure it is.
No, it is not!

[Leans forward and speaks confidentially with a mischievous grin]
What do you want to do to me right now? Come on. Everyone is turning colors. Kids are making out in the street. No one is getting their dinner.
[Raises his voice for all to hear]
Hell, you could have a flood any minute! Pretty soon, the women could be going off to work, while the men stayed at home and cooked!
That is not going to happen!

[with defiant delight]
But it *could* happen!

[enraged]
*No, it could not!*
[Big Bob suddenly turns pink, and David grins victoriously]
Mary Sue?
Yeah?
What goes on up at Lover's Lane?
What do you mean?
Well, you hear these things lately... kids spending so much time up there. Uh, is it holding hands? That kind of thing?
Yeah! That and...
What?
It doesn't matter.
No, I wanna know.
Well, sex.
Oh. What's sex?
[after Mary Sue explains to Betty about sex]
Are you okay?
Um, yes. It's, uh, just that your father would never do anything like that.
Ahhhh.
Mmm.
Well, you know, Mom, there are other ways to enjoy yourself... without Dad.
[Pleasantville's first-ever rainstorm]
Well, we're safe for now. Thank goodness we're in a bowling alley.
Yeah, where's our lawyer?
Oh, I think we want to keep these proceedings as pleasant as possible.
Mary Sue, I think I should go home now.
Why what's wrong?
I think I might be
[looking down]
... ill. Somethings happening to me.

[looking with him]
That's supposed to happen.
It is?
Yeah, trust me.
They're happy like this.
No, David. Nobody's happy in a poodle skirt and a sweater set.
Hey, can I ask you a question?
Sure.
How come I'm still in black and white?
What?

I've had, like, ten times as much sex as the rest of these girls, and I still look like this. I mean, they spend, like, an hour in the back seat of some car and all of a sudden they're in Technicolor?
I don't know. Maybe it's not just the sex.
[Montage of teachers talking to David's classes]

For those of you going on to college next year, the chance of finding a good job will actually decrease by the time you graduate. The available number of entry-level jobs will drop 31 percent over the next four years. Median income for those jobs will go down as well. Obviously, my friends, it's a competitive world, and good grades are your only ticket through. In fact, by the year 2000...
The chance of contracting HIV from a non-monogamous lifestyle will climb to 1 in 150. The odds of dying in an auto accident are only 1 in twenty-five hundred. Now, this marks a drastic increase...

...from fourteen years ago, when ozone depletion was just at 10 percent of its current level. By the time you are thirty years old, average global temperature will have risen two and a half degrees, causing such catastrophic consequences as typhoons, floods, widespread drought, and famine.
[Cut to David absorbing all this grim information and looking really depressed]

]
Okay! Who can tell me what "famine" is?

[on the phone]
Well, he's not homeless, Howard, they just don't say where he lives. - Well, it's a silly question! - Because nobody's homeless in Pleasantville. 'Cause that's just not what it's like.
I don't know if I ever told you this before, but I think you're just about the keenest girl in the whole school!
Oh, really Skip? The keenest?
This place gives me the creeps! Did you know that the books are blank?
What?
Yeah, I was in the library and I looked, and they have covers and there's nothing inside of them.
What were you doing in a library?
I got lost.
Look at me! I'm pasty!
You can pin me anytime, Skip. Or maybe I should just pin you.

[laughs]
That's silly, Mary Sue. How could you possibly pin me?

[townspeople are burning library books]
Mary Sue, it's better this way!
This is the only book I've ever read in my whole life, and you're not going to put it on that fire!
I did the slut thing, David. It got kinda old.
Hiya, Bud!
Hiya, Skip!
Hiya, Bud!
Hiya, Skip!
Bud, can I ask you a question?
Sure.
Well, if I was to go up to your sister... What I mean is, if I was to go up to Mary Sue...
Oh my God... are we in that episode?
I knew you'd pay a price for this. I knew you couldn't be so hopelessly geek-ridden for so long without suffering some really tragic consequences.

[looking at boobs in mirror]
I could, like, kill a guy with these things.
[first lines]
[David is gazing admiringly at a pretty blonde girl]
*Hi*
[chuckles]

I mean, Hi. Uh, look, you probably don't think I should be asking you this. I mean, not knowing you well and all? I mean, you know, I, I, I know you, 'cause everybody knows you. I just don't know you technically. Uh, anyhow. Uh, I don't know what you're doing this weekend, but my mom's leaving town, and she's letting me borrow the car.
[the camera pulls back to show that the girl is standing several dozen feet away and, in fact, is smiling and looking at another boy]

[Looks down at the ground, disappointed with himself, but still keeping his tone cheerful]
Okey-dokey, so, just give me a call; let me know. Bye!
Hey - who did Muffin take to the Masquerade Ball when her date came down with the measles?
Her father.
That's right! And how'd she dress him?
As Prince Charming.
Nice! Remember the one where Bud lost his cousin when he was supposed to be watching him?
Yep.
What department store did they go to?
MacIntyre's.
McGinty's.
No! MacIntyre's! Remember?
[sings a jingle]
"For the very best in men's attire, head right down to MacIntyre's."
[smiles proudly]
That's right.
[Looks consideringly at David]
Listen, uh, why don't you take this remote instead? It's got a little more oomph in it.
Oomph?
Sure! Big beautiful set like that? You want something'll put you right in the show.
[as David takes the remote control, the room fills with supernatural flashes of lightning and a rumble of thunder]
[David and Howard are eating lunch at school and studying for the "Pleasantville" Trivia Competition]
Okay, in the very first "Pleasantville" episode, whose window did Bud break when he was playing with his father's golf clubs?
Mister Jenkins. What job did Mister Jenkins have?
[Howard doesn't know]
Salesman. What did Bud and Mary Sue name the cat they found in the gutter?
Scout?
Marmalade! All right, all right, here's one. Why did their parents come home early from their weekend at the lake?
[Howard doesn't know]
'Cause Bud didn't answer the phone and they were worried about him.
Man. You're unbelievable. You'll win this thing for sure. When is it on?
30, contest is tomorrow at noon.
A thousand bucks, huh? And it's on all night?
Well, of course it is, Howard. That's why they call it a marathon.
I'll see you at school, Mary Sue.
[Jennifer smiles as Skip drives away]
Who's that?
Skip Martin, captain of the basketball team.
Does he like me?
As a matter of fact, he does.
[Jennifer's smile turns slightly lecherous]
[David looks up from his job at the soda counter to see Jennifer determinedly leading Skip out of the place and down the sidewalk]
Oh, shit!
[He takes a flying jump-leap over the counter]
*Jennifer*!
Jennifer, stop!
[He chases Jennifer and Skip outside, to where Skip's car is already pulling away from the curb]
You can't do this, Jennifer! He doesn't exist! You can't do this to someone who doesn't exist!
It's just... where am I going to see colors like that?
You know, your mom went out.
Went out?
Yeah. She went out for a little while.
When?
Three days ago.
What happened? One minute, everything's fine... What went wrong?
Nothing went wrong. People change.
People change?
Yeah, people change.
Can they change back?

[grins]
I don't know. I think it's harder.
[last lines]
So what's going to happen now?
I don't know. Do you know what's going to happen now?
No
[laughing]
...I don't!
I guess I don't either.

I know you miss her, I mean, you told me you did. But maybe it's not just the cooking or the cleaning that you miss. Maybe it's something else. Maybe you can't even describe it. Maybe you only know it when it's gone. Maybe it's like there's a whole piece of you that's missing, too. Look at her, Dad. Doesn't she look pretty like that? Doesn't she look just as beautiful as the first time you met her? Do you really want her back the way she was? Doesn't she look wonderful? Now, don't you wish you could tell her that?
HELLO! I've got like three pounds of underwire on here!
What can I get you two?
Well, Bud, I think I'll have my usual cheeseburger and a Cherry Coke.
Oh, I don't know Bud... I think I'll have a salad and an Evian water...
[Bud gives her a dirty look]
Cheeseburger it is!

[about David]
Oh, my God. He is, like, so pathetic. I can't believe you're, like, related to him!
Only on my parents' side.
Yeah, but you guys are, like, twins and stuff. You must be from the cool side of the uterus.
And I still don't see why we're doing this!
Because we're supposed to be in school.
We're supposed to be at home, David. We're supposed to be in color!

[placatingly]
Okay, okay, okay.
God!
Everybody really likes you, George.
Oh. Well...
No! They do! And it's not just 'cause you're a good bowler. It's 'cause people respect you!
I was thinking of wearing that red thing... it's not slutty!... it's fun.
You listen to me for just a minute! I don't know what you've done to us, but you better fix it!
Shhh!
Fast! I had a date with Mark Davis and I even bought new underwear!
[the geography teacher uses a pointer to demonstrate, on the classroom blackboard, the world of Pleasantville, which consists of Elm Street, Main Street, and the Town Hall]
Last week, class, we discussed the geography of Main Street. This week we're going to be talking about Elm Street. Now, can anyone tell me the difference between Elm Street and Main Street? Tommy.
It's not as long?
That's right, Tommy, it's not as long. Also, it only has houses, so the geography of Main Street is different than the geography of Elm Street.
[Jennifer is frowning in bewilderment. She raises her hand]
Mary Sue!
Yeah. What's outside of Pleasantville?
[the entire class turns to look at her]
I don't understand.
Outside of Pleasantville? Like, what's at the end of Main Street?

[chuckles and shakes her head]
Mary Sue. You should know the answer to that! The end of Main Street is just the beginning again.
[the teacher points at the intersection of Elm and Main. The class feels released to giggle at Jennifer/Mary Sue's clearly stupid question, and Jennifer frowns again]
Betty! Bob would like some of your great hors d'oeuvres!
What's outside of Pleasantville?
Oh, it doesn't matter.
What's outside of Pleasantville?
[pause]
There are some places that the road doesn't go in a circle. There are some places where the road keeps going.
Keeps going?
Yeah, yeah. It just keeps going. It all keeps going.
...Don't you think?
I think you should try not to think about that anymore.
Fire! Fire! Fire! Fire!... Cat?

[on the phone]
It was so amazing, Daff! I was like, "So, my mom's gonna be out of town," and he was like, "Yeah? Well, maybe we could..." and I was like, "Yeah, sure," and he was like, "Cool,"... I know! He is so smart!
I'm getting a little concerned about what I'm seeing on some of these reruns.
Well, I better get going. Your show's almost on.
[after waiting two seconds after knocking on the door]
Bitch...

[Betty is in color, George is still black & white]
George, look at me. Look at my face. That meeting is not for me.
You'll put on some make-up.
I don't want to put on make-up.
It'll go away. It goes away.

[firmly]
I don't want it to go away.
You know, we didn't call for any TV repair.
Well, that just makes it a lucky day for both of us!
[smiles, followed by silence]
Well, it looks like we're going to have another sunny day - high 72, low 72, and not a cloud in the sky.
Must be awfully lucky to see colours like that. I'll bet they don't know how lucky they are.
What's the commotion? Where's the cat?
Just give me the damned remote!
[thunk]
Ow!
